Literature Review: The COVID-19 pandemic, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, has highlighted significant variability in disease severity among infected individuals. While most infections are asymptomatic or mild, approximately 10% of cases progress to hypoxemic COVID-19 pneumonia, a severe and potentially life-threatening condition. This variability has prompted extensive research into the human genetic factors that influence susceptibility to severe COVID-19, with a particular focus on both rare and common genetic variants. Large-scale genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have been instrumental in identifying common genetic loci associated with COVID-19 pneumonia. These studies have revealed more than 20 loci with modest effect sizes, some of which involve genes expressed in the lungs or leukocytes, suggesting a role in immune response and lung function. Notably, the most robust association identified is a haplotype on chromosome 3, inherited from Neanderthals, which has been linked to an increased risk of severe COVID-19. This finding underscores the complex interplay between ancient human genetics and modern disease susceptibility. In addition to common variants, research into rare genetic variants has provided critical insights into the pathogenesis of severe COVID-19. Sequencing studies have identified inborn errors of type I interferon (IFN) immunity in 1–5% of unvaccinated patients with critical pneumonia. Type I IFNs are crucial for antiviral defense, and their impairment can lead to an inadequate immune response to SARS-CoV-2. Furthermore, autoantibodies against type I IFN, which mimic the effects of these inborn errors, have been found in another 15–20% of severe cases. These autoantibodies neutralize the antiviral activity of type I IFNs, thereby exacerbating the severity of COVID-19. The identification of these genetic and autoimmune factors has significant implications for personalized medicine and public health. Understanding the genetic basis of severe COVID-19 can help identify individuals at higher risk and inform targeted interventions, such as prophylactic treatments or vaccination strategies. Moreover, these findings contribute to the broader field of human genomics, illustrating how genetic variation can influence susceptibility to infectious diseases. As research continues, the integration of genetic data with clinical and epidemiological information will be essential for developing effective strategies to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 and future pandemics.
